qas.question: What traits grew among military men that helped Ali maintain rule?

context: <a0_0>Muhammad Ali Pasha<a0_0/> evolved the military from one that convened under the tradition of the corvée to a great modernised army. He introduced conscription of the male peasantry in 19th century Egypt, and took a novel approach to create his great army, <a1_0>strengthening it with numbers and in skill<a1_0/>. Education and training of the new soldiers was not an option; the new concepts were furthermore enforced by isolation. The men were held in barracks <a2_0>to avoid distraction of their growth<a2_0/> as a military unit to be reckoned with. The resentment for the military way of life eventually faded from the men and a new ideology took hold, one of <a3_0>nationalism and pride<a3_0/>. It was with the help of this newly reborn martial unit that Muhammad Ali imposed his rule over Egypt.
